Award.AbstractNarration:
The "Smoky Great Plains Geometry Conference" will be held at Wichita State University on March 17-20, 2014. The conference will feature important areas of geometry and geometric analysis with leading researchers as speakers. There will be 13 plenary lectures with plenty of time between talks to encourage discussion and the interchange of ideas. The funding will help to involve early-career mathematicians, including graduate students and postdocs. Particular attention will be paid to identifying and supporting women and other members of underrepresented groups. The organizers have pledged that at least 50% of the speakers at the conference will be female.


The focus of the conference is on metric geometry in the broadest possible sense and the relationship between global metric geometry and topology, including methods of Riemannian and Semi-Riemannian geometry as well as Alexandrov geometry and other singular geometric spaces. Key areas represented will be Metric geometry, Geometric flows, Lorentzian Geometry, Einstein Metrics, Ricci solitons and Mathematical General Relativity. The overlap between these areas makes very real the possibility for cross-collaboration among the participants.
The webpage for the conference can be found at: http://www.math.wichita.edu/SGPGeometryConference/

POR.DRECONTENT:
We feel the Smoky Great Plains Geometry Conference was a success. There were a total of 13 plenary talks given over 4 days of the conference. 12 of the plenary talks were research talks, and one was a survey talk. In general, all the talks were excellent. The committee organized (as much as possible) talks in terms of unifying ideas. Speakers were able to incorporate information from previous talks or signal results that would be talked about that same day thus helping people to see common themes. Since the talks were in different areas of Metric Geometry, the speakers made an extra effort to make their talks accessible to a general audience of geometers.

The total number of participants, including organizers and speakers was 62. There were 4 organizers and 13 Plenary speakers.

One of the goals of the workshop was to encourage and foster interactions among the geometry groups of institutions in the Southeast and the Midwest. Although the meeting served the mathematics community nationwide, we made a special effort to attract graduate students and researchers from the Southeast and the Midwest. This was in recognition of the fact that several of these institutions are located far from major mathematical centers, and meetings of this nature are not frequent in either region.

 
We were very pleased to have a large number of women participating on all levels as well as post-docs and graduate students. 23 of the 62 participants were women and 37 of the 62 were post-docs, graduate or undergraduate students.

Another important goal of the conference was to raise the visibility of female geometers. We had a 53% representation of women among our plenary speakers this year. A large number of participants were very pleased to see so many women present at the conference and communicated this directly to the organizers. Showing female students by sheer presence that there are women working in this area is a subtle, but effective means of encouraging them to study geometry. From this point of view, we feel that the conference was a tremendous success.

We also held a women's networking luncheon during the meeting, one of whose goals was to introduce the 6th, 7th and 8th grade girls of the Wichita State University Math Circle to women at various stages professionally in mathematics. The meeting was attended by almost 90% of the female participants. It was an excellent opportunity for the younger female participants in the conference to get to know the more senior women in an informal setting and we also hope that it served as some inspiration for the  6th, 7th and 8th grade girls who attended to continue studying a STEM discipline.

We received a large number of unsolicited, extremely favorable comments from students, post-docs and professors and many of the younger participants asked when the next version of the workshop would be held. We have already organized another workshop in 2016 with funding from the NSF which will take place in Tennessee in August, 2016. We  plan to organize another such workshop in 2017 to be held in Wichita again and would like to make it an annual event from then on. We hope that the NSF will consider funding the next such workshop, as well as allowing us to turn this an annual event, so that we can achieve an equivalent level of success.
